articles.title: About Me
articles.description: Musings of an academic without a PhD.
articles.contents:
Academic
BA, Mathematics, University of Montana, 2009
MSc, Mathematics, Portland State University, 2011
By profession I’m an academic. I started my career in January 2012. I’ve been a contingent faculty member the entire time. I currently teach as an adjunct associate professor at Pierce College and as a visiting instructor at Pacific Lutheran University.
Aside from teaching but still under the academic umbrella, I am a contributor with OpenIntro. Specifically I serve as the Data Management Lead. Fancy title that means I maintain an internal R package that serves as an intermediary between a team of volunteers, Data Hunters, and the {openintro} and {usdata} R packages. The Data Hunters compile and cultivate real world data sets for inclusion in the textbook and supplementary materials. If you’re interested in becoming a Data Hunter, please email me!
Runner
In another life, I was a retail store manager at a local Fleet Feet. I spent years running 50+ miles per week and competing in races ranging from 5k’s to 100 miles (* only one of those). At one point I was even a member of (now defunct) PowerBar TeamElite. I still run but I’m not so fast anymore.
Tech Enthusiast
I have always enjoyed technology. I like to tinker and to keep things running as long as I can. I just recently had to replace my laptop after 8 years and am typing this on a 10 year old desktop.
Current Setup(s)
Laptop
Dell G3 3590
CPU: Intel Core i7-9750h
Memory: 16 GB DDR4-2666
Storage (boot): 500 GB Samsung 970 EVO m.2 nvme ssd
Storage: 1 TB Seagate hdd
WiFi: 802.11ax
Graphics: Nvidia GeForce GTX 1650

Dell XPS 8300
CPU: Intel Core i7-2600
CPU Cooler: Thermaltake Gravity i2
Memory: 32 GB DDR3-1333
Storage (boot): 240 GB Seagate BarraCuda ssd
Storage: 500 GB WD Blue hdd
WiFi: 802.11n
Graphics: Nvidia GT 710
Peripherals
Keyboard: Keychron K4
Keyboard: Keychron K6
Mouse: Corsair Harpoon
Monitors: 2 x Dell 27"
NAS
Synology DS 220j
2 x 4 TB Seagate Ironwolf (raid 1)

articles.title: Stat 242
articles.contents: This page will be in development Summer 2021 to serve as a course hub for fall semester.

articles.title: Stat 231
articles.contents:
Stat 231: Introductory Statistics
This course is intended for non-STEM majors.
An emphasis is placed on a broad understanding of topics in sampling methods, basic probability, hypothesis testing, confidence intervals and linear regression.
Course Materials
Our textbook is OpenIntro Statistics: 4th Ed..
A graphing calculator will be useful for some of the computations we will do. Specifically instruction will be provided for the Ti-83/84 and Casio FX-750GII.
We will have a total of seven computer labs using R and RStudio. There will be dedicated class time to installing the software or setting up a cloud account. Those who feel comfortable doing so can download R and RStudio prior to the start of class.
R Package
All materials needed for lab days can be found in the Stat231 R package. Students can install the package by running the code below in the console of RStudio (requires the devtools package). As with R and RStudio, there will be dedicated time in class for this activity.

devtools::install_github(“npaterno/stat231”, build_vignettes = TRUE)

Each lesson can be found as a vignette in the help file. The corresponding assignments are available as RMarkdown templates.
If you happen to be an instructor who has stumbled across this page, you are free to use the package under the CC-BY-SA 4.0 License.
